s.gd: CHAN eil ach beagan is fichead bliadhna bho’n dh’fhalbh an tuath a Hiort gu tìr-mór.
s.en: It is only a bit more than twenty years since the people left Saint Kilda for the mainland.

s.gd: Tha seann eachdraidh an eilein mar tha ar seann-eachdraidh fhéin gu tur air chall, is bhiodh e inntinn-tharruingeach dhuinn fios a bhith againn dé a thug air daoine a thighinn a dh’ fhuireach ann, an toiseach, agus cuin.
s.en: The ancient history of the island is like our own ancient history completely lost, and it would be interesting for us to know what caused people to come to live there, first of all, and when.

s.gd: Anns a’ cheathramh linne deug thug Eòin, Tighearna nan Eilean, sgrìobhadh d’ a mhac Raghnall air Hiort, fo’n ainm sin; sgrìobhadh a bha air aideachadh le Rìgh Raibeart II.
s.en: In the fourteenth century John, Lord of the Isles, wrote to his sone Ronald on Saint Kilda, under that name; writing that had been accepted by King Robert II.

s.gd: An déidh sin fhuair MacLeòid Dhunbheagain seilbh air an àite is bha Hiort aig an teaghlach sin fad chóig ceud bliadhna gus an do dhealaich iad ris an 1930.
s.en: After that MacLeod of Dunvegan got possession of the place and that family had Saint Kilda for five hundred years until they quit it in 1930.

s.gd: Tha e an diugh aig Iarla Dumfris mar chomraich eun.
s.en: Today it is held by the Earl of Dumfries as a bird sanctuary.

s.gd: An uair a thadhail Màirtinn Màirtinn san eilean an 1695 bha 180 de shluagh a’ tuineachadh ann; thanaich an àireamh sin gu 88 an 1759.
s.en: When Martin Martin visited the island in 1695 there were 180 people dwelling there; that number dropped to 88 in 1759.

s.gd: Thuit sin a rithis gu 72 an 1875 is an 1930 bha e air crìonadh cho beag ri 35.
s.en: That fell again to 72 in 1875 and in 1930 it had dropped as low as 35.

s.gd: Thàinig sgrios air sluagh an eilein le breac, uair no dhà, is an 1856 chaidh 35 thairis gu Astràlia ach gu mì-fhortunach chailleadh móran diubh air an t-slighe null le tinneas.
s.en: Destruction came to the people pf the island with smallpox, once or twice, and in 1856 35 went over to Australia but unfortunately many of them were lost on the way there with disease.

s.gd: Bha, cuideachd, galair glé thric measg na cloinne a b’ òige san eilean agus is gann a shàbhaileadh leth ’s a thigeadh do’n t-saoghal.
s.en: Also, disease was very frequent among the youngest children on the island and barely half survived and made it to the world.

s.gd: Nuair a chrìon àireamh nan Hiortach an 1930 cha robh air an eilean ach ochdnar fhirionnach slàn, fallain, comasach air obair fhear a chumail a’ dol, a’ chlòimhe a spìonadh is fhighe, ballachan a’ thogail is tighean a’ chàradh, sìol is buntàta a chur is eòin na mara a ghlacadh, mar bu dual le’n athraichean.
s.en: When the number of Saint Kildans dwindled in 1930 there were only on the island eight men who were healthy, able bodied, capable of keeping man’s work going, spinning and knitting the wool, building walls and repairing houses, sowing seeds and potatoes and catching seabirds, as was the tradition with their fathers.

s.gd: Ri linn Mhàirtinn is fada na dhéidh bha e an cead an stiùbhaird, an t-oifigeach bha aig MacLeòid air an eilean, mu leth cheud de na daoine bu mheanbha is bu chaoile ’s na h-eileanaibh mun cuairt a thoirt leis do Hiort air son ràithe samhraidh.
s.en: In Martin's time and long after, it was in permission of the steward, MacLeod's officer on the island, to bring along about fifty of the smallest and thinnest in the surrounding islands to Saint Kilda for the summer season.

s.gd: Thilleadh iad le sunnd is slàinte ’nan gnùis an déidh trì mìosan de àile a’ chuain shiar is pailteas de bhiadh math.
s.en: They would return with heartiness and health in their faces after three months of the Atlantic Ocean atmosphere and plenty of good food.

s.gd: Bha crodh is caoraich aca is eòin fhiadhaich, fulmair, seumais ruadha, sùlairean, sgairbh is buthaigirean.
s.en: They had cattle and sheep and wild birds, fulmars, puffins, gannets, cormorants and more puffins.

s.gd: Iasg ùr, nan dèanadh langa is trosg is sgadan e.
s.en: New fish, if ling and cod and herring would do it.

s.gd: Ach dh’ fheumte acfhuinn iasgaich freagarrach air son an cosnadh is bàta tapaidh.
s.en: But appropriate fishing tackle was needed for earning and a hardy boat.

s.gd: Faodaidh sinn a bhith cinnteach gun robh na Hiortaich toilichte deireadh an t-samhraidh fhaicinn gus am faigheadh iad cothrom ceart biadh a sholair is min a bhleith dhaibh fhéin.
s.en: We may be sure that the Saint Kildans were happy to see the end of the summer so that they would get a proper opportunity to gather food and to mill flour for themselves.

s.gd: Bha sia sloinnidhean am measg nan Hiortach:—Gilliosa, MacFhearghuis, MacDhòmhnuill, MacCuidhean, MacIonmhuinn agus MacCruimein.
s.en: There were six surnames among the Saint Kildans:–Gillies, Ferguson, Donaldson, MacQueen, MacKinven and MacCrimmon.

s.gd: Ma bha sloinnidhean eile ann tha iad air chall an diugh.
s.en: If there were other surnames they are lost today.

s.gd: Tha so a’ dearbhadh gur h-e Gaidheil air fad a bh’ unnta agus tha luchd-rannsachaidh de’n bheachd nach e gineil nan ceud Hiortach a bha san eilean an 1930 ge b’ e air bith co as a thàinig iad.
s.en: This shows that they were all Gaels and researchers are of the opinion that it was not the progeny of the first Saint Kildans who were on the island in 1930 wherever they came from.

s.gd: Bha iad fhéin a’ smaoineachadh gur h-ann a Uidhist a thàinig an athraichean.
s.en: They themselves thought that it was from Uist that their fathers came.

s.gd: Tha ainm no dhà an Hiort a tha nas sine na ám nan Lochlannach.
s.en: There are one or two names in Saint Kilda that are older than the time of the Vikings.

s.gd: Tha againn ainm an eilein fhéin bho’n t-seann Ghàidhlig: hirt, irt, (i.e. bàs) ainm co-cheangailte ris gach cruaidh-chàs is fòirneart a choinnicheadh neach troimh a bhith fuireach san àite iomallach so a tha, am beachd sluagh Innse Gall, na dhubh-phrìosan ’s chan e pàrras (MacBhàtair).
s.en: We have the name of the island itself from old Gaelic: hirt, irt (i.e. death) a name connected with every hardship and violence that somepne would meet through living in this remote place which is, in the opinion of the people of the Hebrides, a dark prison and not a paradise.

s.gd: Tha againn cuideachd Dun Fir Volg (i.e. Dun Fear Bholg)—Daingneach nam Fear Bhalg.
s.en: We also have Dun Fir Volg (i.e. Dun Fear Bholg)–Stronghold of the Bag Men.

s.gd: Thaobh an t-ainm St. Kilda, cha robh naomh air an robh an t-ainm is chan eil.
s.en: Regarding the name St. Kilda, there was not and is not a saint of that name.

s.gd: Tha am facal a’ ciallachadh “tobair”—Kelda ’s a’ chànain Lochlannaich—is tha e r’ a fhaicinn an cairt mara Olaindeach (1666).
s.en: The word means “well”–Kelda in the Norse language–and it is to be seen on a Dutch maritime map (1666).

s.gd: Tha an tobair faisg air an laimhrig far am biodh na h-Olaindich a’ tadhal nuair a bhiodh iad ag iasgach ’s a’ chuan shiar san t-seachdamh linne deug.
s.en: The well is near the harbour where the Dutch would visit when they would be fishing on the Atlantic ocean in the seventeenth century.

s.gd: Tha cuideachd tighean fo thalamh ann is altairean pàganach is tursachan cloiche a’ nochdadh làmh an duine is a làthaireachd bho shean.
s.en: There are also underground houses and pagan altars and standing stones manifesting the hand of man and his presence from old.
